author: Ismael López Domínguez
title: Tres países unen esfuerzos y dinero para fabricar un avión militar ultramoderno: será invisible y supersónico
text:
Hace más de un año, Reino Unido, Japón e Italia sugirieron aunar esfuerzos para poder desarrollar un avión militar tipo caza que fuera furtivo y de velocidad supersónica. En el papel que se redactó, y que ahora se ha firmado, se especifica que la aeronave debe estar “equipado con tecnología punta”. En un mundo donde la tecnología de última generación cada vez es mayor, estos tres países buscan competir contra Estados Unidos y China.
Ahora mismo en el mundo Estados Unidos y China lideran la carrera armamentística . A pesar del accidente que se produjo hace algún tiempo, la fuerza aérea estadounidense dispone del potente caza F-35. Un avión que ya está comercializando con los miembros de la OTAN. Por otro lado, China está realizando simulaciones de guerra y con ellas ha comprobado que puede derribar el bombardero más moderno de Estados Unidos . Reino Unido, Italia y Japón tendrán un nuevo caza de combate en 2035
Aparte de esto, otros actores globales como son Reino Unido, Italia y Japón quieren hacerse un hueco en esta carrera. Y por ello quieren desarrollar un caza de última generación. Leyendo lo que ha publicado el pasado 14 de diciembre el gobierno británico, el futuro caza furtivo tendrá el objetivo de mejorar la capacidad militar , prosperidad y beneficios estratégicos de los tres países.
Además de estos, el trabajo tendrá sede en Reino Unido y brindará cientos de puestos de trabajo. El proyecto también apoyará la futura estabilidad del teatro Indo-Pacífico y una seguridad global más amplia .
De acuerdo con la misma fuente, el avión de combate propuesto alzará el vuelo en 2035 y podría convertirse en una de las aeronaves más avanzadas, interoperables y adaptables a nivel mundial .
Entre la tecnología que se ha mencionado que incorporará aparece un potente radar que es capaz de proporcionar 10.000 veces más datos que los sistemas actuales, lo que le brindará la una ventaja significativa para ganar las batallas que tenga que luchar .
El proyecto, liderado por Reino Unido, será reforzado y liderado por empresas como BAE Systems, junto con la estrecha ayuda de Rolls-Royce, Leonardo UK y MBDA UK. Así como otros cientos de empresas de todo el país que suministrarán distintos materiales en la cadena de suministro. En conclusión se puede decir que: Reino Unido, Italia y Japón pretenden mejorar su influencia mundial con un nuevo avión de combate. El caza será furtivo y supersónico y llevará a bordo la mejor tecnología. Se espera que la aeronave pueda ser fabricada y puesta en vuelo para 2035.
El artículo Tres países unen esfuerzos y dinero para fabricar un avión militar ultramoderno: será invisible y supersónico fue publicado originalmente en Urban Tecno .

author: Enviroliteracy Team
title: Where should you not use expanding foam?
text:
Where Not to Use Expanding Foam: A Comprehensive Guide Expanding foam is a remarkably versatile product, capable of sealing gaps, insulating spaces, and even providing structural support in some applications. However, its very nature – that unstoppable expansion – means it’s crucial to understand where not to use it to avoid costly mistakes and potential hazards. Using it correctly can provide many benefits, but knowing its limitations is essential for successful projects.
The short answer? Avoid using expanding foam in electrical boxes, around high-heat sources, on surfaces with high moisture content, in areas requiring future access, on delicate or non-structural materials, and in applications where precise dimensional control is paramount. Let’s break down each of these scenarios in detail.
Situations Where Expanding Foam Is a No-Go 1. Electrical Boxes and Enclosures Expanding foam and electricity simply don’t mix. The primary reason is heat buildup . Electrical wires generate heat as current flows through them. Normally, this heat dissipates into the surrounding air. However, encasing wires in expanding foam acts as an insulator, preventing heat from escaping. This can lead to:
Overheating and melting of wire insulation: This creates a fire hazard and potential electrical shorts. Damage to electrical components: Outlets, switches, and other devices within the box can overheat and fail prematurely. Difficulty in future repairs or modifications: Removing foam from an electrical box is a messy and potentially destructive process, hindering future work. Instead of expanding foam, use fire-rated caulk or putty designed specifically for sealing around electrical boxes. These materials provide an airtight seal without the risk of trapping heat or damaging components.
2. Around High-Heat Sources Similar to electrical boxes, applying expanding foam near heat sources like furnaces, water heaters, fireplaces, and recessed lighting fixtures presents a significant fire hazard. Cured expanding foam is combustible. The article mentioned that cured foam is combustible and will burn if exposed to temperatures above 240°F (116°C). Although it may be fire-resistant to a certain degree, continuous exposure to high temperatures can cause it to degrade, shrink, and potentially ignite. Always check the manufacturer’s specifications for temperature limits.
Choose non-combustible insulation materials specifically designed for high-heat applications. Mineral wool (Rockwool) or specialized high-temperature silicone sealants are suitable alternatives.
3. Surfaces with High Moisture Content Expanding foam requires a clean, dry surface to properly adhere. If the surface has a moisture content exceeding 20% , the foam will likely fail to bond correctly. This can lead to:
Poor adhesion: The foam will peel away from the surface, negating its insulating and sealing properties. Mold and mildew growth: Moisture trapped behind the foam creates an ideal environment for microbial growth, potentially leading to health problems and structural damage. The article also mentioned that spray foam insulation can be susceptible to mold and mildew growth if water gets into it after application. Material degradation: Over time, the trapped moisture can cause the surrounding materials (wood, drywall, etc.) to rot or corrode. Ensure the surface is thoroughly dry before applying expanding foam. Use a moisture meter to verify the moisture content is within acceptable limits. If the area is prone to moisture, address the underlying cause before attempting any insulation or sealing work.
4. Areas Requiring Future Access Expanding foam is notoriously difficult to remove. Once it’s cured, it forms a rigid, adhesive mass that bonds tightly to most surfaces. Using it in areas where you might need access in the future – such as behind panels, under floors, or around plumbing lines – can create major headaches. The article mentioned that spray foam can be more difficult to remove. Removing it often requires:
Destructive methods: Cutting, scraping, and chiseling, potentially damaging the surrounding materials. Significant time and effort: What might have been a simple repair becomes a complicated and time-consuming process. Potential for hidden damage: Inadvertently damaging wires, pipes, or other components hidden behind the foam. Consider using removable insulation options, such as fiberglass batts, mineral wool, or rigid foam boards, in areas where future access is required. These materials can be easily removed and replaced without causing damage.
5. On Delicate or Non-Structural Materials Expanding foam exerts considerable pressure as it cures. Applying it to delicate or non-structural materials, such as thin plastic sheeting, lightweight trim, or fragile surfaces , can cause:
Distortion and warping: The expansion pressure can deform or buckle the material. Cracking or breaking: Fragile materials may not be able to withstand the force of the expanding foam. Cosmetic damage: The foam can seep into cracks and crevices, creating an unsightly mess. Exercise caution when applying expanding foam to materials that are not structurally sound. Consider using a low-expansion foam specifically designed for delicate surfaces, or opt for a different sealing or insulation method altogether.
6. Applications Requiring Precise Dimensional Control Expanding foam, as its name suggests, expands significantly after application. This expansion is difficult to control precisely, making it unsuitable for applications requiring tight tolerances or accurate dimensions. Examples include:
Filling intricate molds or forms: The uncontrolled expansion can distort the mold or prevent proper casting. Creating perfectly smooth surfaces: The uneven expansion can create bumps, ridges, and other imperfections. Sealing moving parts or mechanisms: The foam can interfere with the movement of these parts. Opt for materials that offer more predictable and controllable expansion, such as epoxy resins, specialized sealants, or pre-molded components.
7. Applications Exposed to Direct Sunlight The UV rays of the sun can degrade expanding foam over time, causing it to become brittle and crumble. While this may take a while, it is something to consider. The article mentioned that spray foam insulation can last anywhere from 80 years to 100 years. Therefore, it should be protected from exposure.
Protect expanding foam from direct sunlight by covering it with a UV-resistant coating or material. This will help to extend its lifespan and prevent it from breaking down.
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) About Expanding Foam 1. Is all expanding foam the same? No. There are two main types: open-cell and closed-cell foam . Open-cell foam is less dense, more flexible, and has a lower R-value (insulation value). It is also not water-resistant. Closed-cell foam is denser, more rigid, has a higher R-value, and is water-resistant. The article indicated that it is known as open-cell due to half its cells being open. However, this form of expanding foam is not water-resistant or waterproof whereas closed-cell foams are. Also known as polyurethane foam, the cells are interlocked and this prevents any air or water from getting through.
2. Can I use expanding foam to fill large gaps? Yes, but in layers. Applying too much foam at once can result in excessive expansion and potentially damage surrounding materials. Apply in thin layers, allowing each layer to fully cure before applying the next.
3. Is expanding foam waterproof? Not all expanding foam is waterproof. Closed-cell foam is water-resistant, while open-cell foam is not. The article discussed that, as such, it is not water-resistant. Choose the appropriate type based on your specific needs.
4. How do I remove expanding foam? Mechanical removal is usually required. Use a utility knife, scraper, or chisel to carefully remove the foam. Solvents like acetone can soften the foam, but they can also damage certain surfaces.
5. Can rodents chew through expanding foam? Yes. The article mentioned that rodents and small animals, if determined enough, can chew through many materials, including Great Stuff™ foam. While expanding foam can help seal entry points, it’s not a foolproof rodent deterrent.
6. Does expanding foam insulate well? Yes. Both open-cell and closed-cell foam provide good insulation, but closed-cell foam has a higher R-value . The article mentioned that closed cell spray foam has an R-value of R-7 per inch and that open cell spray foam has an R-value of R-3.8 per inch.
7. Can I paint over expanding foam? Yes, but you may need to sand it first to create a smooth surface. Use a primer before painting.
8. What is the shelf life of expanding foam? Typically 12-18 months. Check the manufacturer’s date code on the can.
9. Is expanding foam environmentally friendly? Expanding foam contains man-made chemicals that are not eligible for recycling. The article discussed that these chemicals aren’t sustainable because they pollute the air. Consider eco-friendly alternatives, such as cotton denim, which enviroliteracy.org advocates as a sustainable building material.
10. Can expanding foam cause structural damage? Yes, if used incorrectly. Applying it to weak structures can cause warping or cracking. The article mentioned that if spray foam insulation is applied to an unsuitable structure, it may cause structural issues such as warping or cracking of walls and ceilings, which can reduce property value.
11. Is expanding foam combustible? Yes, cured foam is combustible and will burn if exposed to high temperatures. The article mentioned that cured foam is combustible and will burn if exposed to temperatures above 240°F (116°C).
12. Can I use expanding foam to fill rotten wood? No. The article mentioned that if the wood is really rotted, it has lost structural integrity. Wood filler or spray-in foam insulation will not resolve the problem in a helpful way. Repair or replace the rotten wood first.
13. What is the best expanding foam for sealing windows and doors? Low-expansion foam designed specifically for windows and doors is ideal.
14. Is DIY spray foam insulation worth it? For small projects, yes. But for larger projects, hiring a professional is often more cost-effective and ensures proper application. The article mentioned that it will probably be cheaper to hire a contractor even for a job as little as a rim joist.
15. How does spray foam affect a home’s ability to “breathe?” Spray foam, especially closed-cell, can create an airtight seal. Proper ventilation is crucial to prevent moisture buildup and maintain healthy indoor air quality. The article discussed that insulating an attic roof with spray foam makes it part of the conditioned space in your home and that air will circulate from the living space up to the attic, hit the spray foam barrier, and then move back down.
By understanding the limitations and potential hazards of expanding foam, you can ensure its safe and effective use in your projects. Remember to always follow the manufacturer’s instructions and consult with a professional if you have any doubts.

author: Laurent Bodin
title: Social. Novartis Huningue : la direction assume la suppression de 50 postes
text:
Social Novartis Huningue : la direction assume la suppression de 50 postes
La direction du site Novartis de Huningue a justifié, ce vendredi dans un communiqué, la [suppression de 50 postes équivalents temps plein](/economie/2024/11/28/plus-de-50-emplois-supprimes-en-2025-chez-novartis-a-huningue) en 2025....
Connectez-vous ou créez un compte
Pour pouvoir enregistrer un article, un compte est nécessaire.
L'Alsace, en tant que responsable de traitement, recueille dans ce formulaire des informations qui sont enregistrées dans un fichier informatisé par son Service Relations Clients, la finalité étant d’assurer la création et la gestion de votre compte, ainsi que des abonnements et autres services souscrits. Si vous y avez consenti, ces données peuvent également être utilisées pour l’envoi de newsletters et/ou d’offres promotionnelles par L'Alsace, les sociétés qui lui sont affiliées et/ou ses partenaires commerciaux. Vous pouvez exercer en permanence vos droits d’accès, rectification, effacement, limitation, opposition, retirer votre consentement et/ou pour toute question relative au traitement de vos données à caractère personnel en contactant [s.lecteur@lalsace.fr](mailto:s.lecteur@lalsace.fr) ou consulter les liens suivants : [Protection des données](/protection-des-donnees), [CGU du site](/espace-client/cgu) et [Contact](/contact). Le Délégué à la Protection des Données personnelles ([dpo@ebra.fr](mailto:dpo@ebra.fr)) est en copie de toute demande relative à vos informations personnelles.
La direction du site Novartis de Huningue a justifié, ce vendredi dans un communiqué, la [suppression de 50 postes équivalents temps plein](/economie/2024/11/28/plus-de-50-emplois-supprimes-en-2025-chez-novartis-a-huningue) en 2025....

author: CBC
title: Former Saskatoon mayoral candidate charged with robbery, assault at motel in North Battleford, Sask.
text:
Read full article CBC Former Saskatoon mayoral candidate charged with robbery, assault at motel in North Battleford, Sask. CBC April 10, 2025 at 12:42 a.m. · 2 min read
Link Copied
The Hitching Post Motel remains closed since the robbery. (Dan Zakreski/CBC - image credit) A man who ran for mayor in Saskatoon in 2020 is one of three charged with armed robbery, assault and other offences after a robbery at a hotel in North Battleford, Sask.
Mark Zielke ran unsuccessfully for Saskatoon mayor in 2020, placing sixth in a field of six.
Zielke, 41, is accused alongside Tyson Moore, 44, and David Dominguez, 41, of robbing the Hitching Post Motel on Saturday night. The trio were arrested after RCMP stopped Zielke's white BMW X3 at the Borden Bridge, 50 kilometres northwest of Saskatoon.
Zielke appeared by video Wednesday in North Battleford provincial court. He made bail and is scheduled to return April 28.
ADVERTISEMENT Bail hearings for Moore and Dominguez are set on Thursday.
Mark Zielke posted this selfie on X, on April 4, the day before his arrest. Mark Zielke posted this selfie on X on April 4, the day before his arrest. (Mark Zielke/X)
RCMP offered a narrative of events in a news release and supporting court documents.
Officers responded to the Hitching Post at about 10:40 p.m. CST on Saturday after reports of a robbery. They arrived to find a motel staffer injured and were told three suspects had made off with cash, electronics, ID and financial cards, according to the news release.
Cameras at the Lone Star Hotel next door captured the white BMW leaving the scene, staff told CBC.
RCMP stopped the car at the Borden Bridge and arrested the three men.
All three men are facing 14 charges related to the robbery.
The court documents allege Zielke had a loaded, unregistered Glock 19 handgun and a sword inside the car. He's also charged with confining and threatening to kill motel staff, and damaging the motel CCTV cameras.
ADVERTISEMENT It's alleged that he assaulted the motel staffer with a large ring. On his social media profile on X, Zielke is shown wearing an oversized ring with a Lady Justice insignia.
Zielke uses this photo of his Justice ring on X. Zielke showing off a ring on X. (Mark Zielke/X)
In addition to running for mayor, Zielke is well known in the local legal community for his advocacy work. Although he is not licensed in Saskatchewan as a practising lawyer, he offers to represent people in small claims and traffic court through his business, Living Sky Advocates.
In 2019, a Court of Queen's Bench judge ordered Zielke to stop giving legal advice or acting for clients in court until he is licensed by the Law Society of Saskatchewan.
In 2021, Saskatchewan's Court of Appeal overruled that decision.
topics: Crime, Law and Justice->robbery and theft

author: Hayley Watts
title: Breakthrough in osteoarthritis treatment helps dogs in Northern California | Wellness Wednesday | actionnewsnow.com
text:
CHICO, Calif. - Arthritis is a leading reason for euthanizing older pets, but a new treatment called Synovetin OA is offering hope to pet owners. This breakthrough is promising to change the lives of dogs suffering specifically from osteoarthritis.
Rayna Pitter was devastated when her English Bull Terrier Sookie started limping around. "Sookie had arthritis in her left elbow... it progressed to not being able to walk on stairs, to the point where she could not put her paw to the ground," Pitter said.
Pitter tried various treatments to no avail. "We had CT’s, X-rays, everything you can imagine, bone biopsies, just to find something that could relieve this extreme pain and nothing seemed to do it," she said.
Pitter then discovered Synovetin OA, a new treatment that offered relief. "Sookie was the second dog in Northern California to be treated, so we kind of just lucked into it, that this treatment was out there," she said.
Dr. Erin Troy, a veterinarian at Muller Veterinary Hospital, has seen positive results with Synovetin OA. "I'm very excited about what we've seen. Not only have I used it on patients but also on my own dog, and I've seen an improvement in every dog we've treated," said Troy.
"What it does is go into the joint and binds to two cells, only, and those are the cells that cause the most pain in the joints. Every time those cells are produced, it gobbles them up and keeps the dog from experiencing pain," she said.
For dogs in the early stages of the disease, Synovetin OA may be a suitable option. "It has the ability to slow down the disease," Troy said.
The Pitters also treated their dog Roxy with Synovetin OA, and Sookie lived a happy life until age 13. "She was able to live out her golden years the way she should, she was running, she was playing up until the end, she was happy. We really couldn’t have asked for more," Pitter said.

author: Brian Ajon
title: Peter Miracle Baby Announces He's Now Pastor, Vows to Walk with God: "Hakuna Kurudi Nyuma" - Tuko.co.ke
text: Peter Miracle Baby Announces He's Now Pastor, Vows to Walk with God: "Hakuna Kurudi Nyuma" - Reformed Gengetone artiste Peter Miracle Baby has been anointed as a servant of God - The young man shared his new path on social media with several photos from the church ceremony - Peter thanked Apostle John Paul for officially making him a pastor and invited followers to join him for a live sermon Former Sailors Gang member Peter Miracle Baby has begun a new chapter in his life. The young man received anointing to become a pastor on Sunday, June 2. Peter Miracle Baby's receives Christ The musician took to social media to announce this new journey and shared photos of him in church alongside his spiritual father John Paul. PAY ATTENTION: Share your outstanding story with our editors! Please reach us through news@tuko.co.ke or WhatsApp: 0732482690. Miracle Baby also vowed to serve the Almighty God without backsliding. "Thank you Apostle John Paul for making me pastor officially Now nikumtumikia mungu Bila kurudi nyuma kama kawaida Leo Tupatane live from 6pm-7pm tuskie NENO PAMOJA," he wrote. How Miracle Baby was welcomed from hospital About two months ago, Miracle Baby was discharged from the hospital after his plea from Kenyans to help him raise money to pay treatment bills. Miracle Baby had been in the hospital for 60 days after undergoing three successful surgeries but could not leave until he paid his medical fees. However, in a new video shared on TikTok by @mburu_makeup, the musician could be seen in high spirits as he walked around his house meeting people. He wore a loose hospital shirt and tiny shorts that covered the catheter he was wearing, and he said hello to people who were excited to welcome him back home. The house was also covered with huge white and golden balloons with one written "Welcome home Peter" shared on the wall. William Ruto donates KSh 300k to Miracle Baby As we previously told you, President William Ruto sent Jaguar, Karangu Muraya and other local artistes to deliver his KSh 300,000 to Miracle Baby. According to Muraya, Ruto also directed that he be taken to the hospital and that his medical bills be paid . While sharing the funds, they also passed the president's warm message. Source: TUKO.co.ke []https://www.tuko.co.ke/authors/brian-ajon/ Brian Ajon (Entertainment Editor) Brian Ajon is a journalist accredited by The Media Council of Kenya with close to three years of experience in print and digital media. At Tuko.co.ke, he is an Entertainment Editor (joined in 2021). He holds a Bachelor's Degree in Communication and Media Technology with IT from Maseno University. Ajon is also the Newsletter Editor of the Maseno University Alumni Association (MSU-AA) and He is keen on entertainment and viral stories. Email: brian.ajon@tuko.co.ke.
